name: Shekinah (Divine Presence)
displayName: Shekinah - The Glory of God's Dwelling
description: The Shekinah (Hebrew: shekhinah, from shakan - 'to dwell') is the manifest presence of God dwelling among His people. Appearing as cloud and fire, the Shekinah filled the Tabernacle and Solomon's Temple, led Israel through the wilderness, descended upon Mount Sinai, and appeared at the Transfiguration of Jesus. It represents God's nearness and glory made visible.
significance: The visible manifestation of God's invisible presence
Symbol of divine protection and guidance
Anticipation of ultimate divine dwelling with humanity

etymology.development: The term 'Shekinah' itself does not appear in Scripture but was developed in rabbinic literature to describe God's manifest presence

biblicalManifestations.description: God appeared to Moses in fire that did not consume the bush
biblicalManifestations.significance: First theophany calling Moses to deliver Israel

biblicalManifestations.description: The LORD went before Israel in a pillar of cloud by day and pillar of fire by night
biblicalManifestations.significance: Divine guidance and protection through the wilderness

biblicalManifestations.description: The mountain was covered with cloud, and the glory of the LORD settled on it like consuming fire
biblicalManifestations.significance: The giving of the Torah in the midst of divine glory

biblicalManifestations.description: The cloud covered the Tent of Meeting, and the glory of the LORD filled the tabernacle
biblicalManifestations.significance: God's dwelling among His people established

biblicalManifestations.description: The cloud filled the temple, and the priests could not minister because of the glory
biblicalManifestations.significance: Permanent dwelling of God's presence in Jerusalem

biblicalManifestations.description: Ezekiel saw the glory of the LORD depart from the Temple before the Babylonian destruction
biblicalManifestations.significance: Divine presence withdrew due to Israel's sin

biblicalManifestations.description: A bright cloud overshadowed Jesus, Moses, and Elijah, and the Father's voice spoke from the cloud
biblicalManifestations.significance: The Shekinah glory present with Christ, witnessed by Peter, James, and John

transfigurationConnection.theCloud: The 'bright cloud' that overshadowed Jesus, Moses, and Elijah is the Shekinah - the same glory cloud that covered Sinai and filled the Tabernacle
transfigurationConnection.theVoice: The Father's voice from the cloud ('This is my beloved Son') echoes the voice from Sinai
transfigurationConnection.peterSuggestion: Peter's offer to build three tabernacles (sukkot) reflects the Feast of Tabernacles, when Israel commemorated God's dwelling presence in the wilderness
transfigurationConnection.jamesPerspective: As one of three witnesses, James son of Zebedee saw the Shekinah glory and heard the Father's voice - the same divine presence that had appeared to Moses at Sinai
transfigurationConnection.theologicalMeaning: The Transfiguration revealed that the Shekinah glory now dwelt in and upon Christ - 'the Word became flesh and tabernacled among us, and we beheld his glory' (John 1:14)

rabbinicTeaching.presenceWithIsrael: Where Israel goes into exile, the Shekinah goes with them
rabbinicTeaching.presenceInStudy: When two sit and study Torah, the Shekinah rests between them
rabbinicTeaching.feminineAspect: In Kabbalah, the Shekinah is associated with the feminine aspect of the Divine
rabbinicTeaching.indwelling: The Shekinah dwells with those who are humble and contrite
rabbinicTeaching.awaiting: The Shekinah awaits Israel's repentance to return in full glory

christianUnderstanding.incarnation: The Shekinah glory dwelt in Jesus Christ in bodily form (Colossians 2:9)
christianUnderstanding.johnsPrologue: The Word became flesh and 'tabernacled' (eskēnōsen) among us, and we beheld his glory (John 1:14)
christianUnderstanding.holySpirit: The Shekinah now indwells believers through the Holy Spirit (1 Corinthians 6:19)
christianUnderstanding.futureGlory: The New Jerusalem will have no temple, for the Lord God Almighty and the Lamb are its temple (Revelation 21:22)
christianUnderstanding.transfiguration: At the Transfiguration, the veil was briefly lifted and the apostles saw Christ's pre-existent glory

symbolism.cloud: Represents both God's presence and the veil that protects humans from full exposure to divine glory
symbolism.fire: Represents God's holiness, purity, and consuming nature
symbolism.light: Represents divine truth, guidance, and the dispelling of darkness
symbolism.gold: The gold of the Tabernacle and Temple represented the Shekinah's radiance

sukkotConnection.symbolism: Living in booths commemorates God's dwelling presence with Israel in the wilderness
sukkotConnection.waterLibation: The water ceremony during Sukkot anticipated the outpouring of the Spirit
sukkotConnection.jesusAtSukkot: Jesus declared 'I am the light of the world' during Sukkot (John 8:12), claiming to be the true Shekinah
sukkotConnection.transfigurationTiming: Some scholars suggest the Transfiguration may have occurred near the time of Sukkot, explaining Peter's mention of tabernacles

relatedConcepts: Kavod (Glory) - The weight or majesty of God
